div1.p: Personnelle.
Baltimore, le 15 fevrier 1909.
Monsieur le Ministre,

Vu que le révérend S.H. Chester, comme representant des missionaires presbytériens au Congo a demandé l'intervention du Consul Général Américain, à Boma, dans le procès Morrison (annexe 1.) et qu'il saisis l'occasion de mettre l'affaire dans un faux jour dans les journaux, j'ai cru utile de donner une entrevue à la presse afin de corriger l’opinion publique. (annexe 2)

J'aurais pu faire répandre un communiqué plus en détail et plus autorisé sinon que je fusse empêché par manque de fonctions officielles. Les nouvelles d'une source officielle sont beaucoup plus écoutées et beaucoup plus repandues.
Veuillez agréer, Monsieur le Ministre, l'assurance de ma considération la plus distinguée.
Whiteley
div1.fw: Son Excellence Monsieur Renkin Ministre des Colonies Bruxelles.

div1.p: Annexe 1.
The Times, Washington, le 5 fevrier 1909.
Missionary Asks Inquiry On Congo
Secretary of State Told Libel Suits Threaten Religious Workers.

The Rev. S. H. Chester, D. D., of Nashville representing the missionary department of the Southern Presbyterian Church, called upon Secretary Bacon today to request that the State Department through Consul General W. W. Handley at Boma, investigate the circumstances of the trial of the American missionaries who are charged with libel by the authorities of the Congo Free State in connection with their reports on the conditions of the natives.

The reports of the missionaries, of whom there are several alleged that through the labor imposed upon the natives, the Bakuba tribe has been reduced to a condition of famine, and that the men who are obliged to turn in certain amounts of rubber of ivory each year have so little time to devote to crop-raising that they are unable to sustain themselves and their families. Included in the reports were pictures of natives in chains because they had failed to comply with the demands of the government.

The libel suit is not the first to be brought by the Congo authorities for alleged offenses of this kind. Edgar Stannard, a British missionary, was tried and found guilty. It was charged by the missionaries that certain evidence was suppressed in order to give a basis for a verdict.
It is to forestall any action of this kind that Dr. Chester has requested the State Department to keep the trial under observation.
Annexe 2.
The Herald, Washington, le 11 fevrier 1909.
Whiteley

Consul General Wheatley, of the Congo Free State, who was seen at the New Willard, spoke in regard to the reported request made of Secretary Bacon by a representative of the Souther Presbyterian Church that an investigation be made into the circumstances of the trial of certain American missionaries in the Congo Free State for libel, in connection with their reports of the condition of the natives, and said:

"The trouble seems to have arisen from the fact that certain Protestant missionaries in the Congo, who apparently have little sympathy with the language, laws, or religion of the Belgians, have wanted to run the country according to their own ideas, and have used indiscreet language about Belgian officers who disagreed with them.

"According to the accounts which we have from trustworthy sources in the Congo, Count Ferdinand de Grunne, who is a young man of high reputation, and a member of one of the best families in Belgium, found it his duty, for the maintenance of public order, to compel certain natives who were loafing about the American Presbyterian Mission at Luebo to return to the tribes to which they belonged—just as the American government compels the Indians to stay on their reservations. For this action some of the American missionaries seem to have called him names, and brought charges for cruelty, and even of slave-raiding, against him. It seems that the Rev. Mr. Morrison, of the American Presbyterian Mission, was the chief person with whom Count de Grunne had disputations. Then Count de Grunne brought suit for libel."
Private.
Baltimore, 15 February 1909.
Mr. Minister,

Given that the reverend S.H. Chester, as representative of Presbyterian missionaries in the Congo asked for the intervention of the American Consul General, in Boma, in the Morrison proceedings (annex 1.) and that he seize the opportunity to misrepresent the case in the newspapers, I believed it necessary to give a meeting to the press in order to correct public opinion. (annex 2)
I could have spread a report more detailed and more official except I was prevented by a lack of official duties. News from an official source was listened to far more and far more widespread.
Please accept, Sir, the assurance of my most distinguished consideration
Whiteley
